Objectives

Understand the parameters of a linear model, slope and y-intercept, and the roles of these parameters in changing the shape of the model.

Be able to interpret the meaning of the parameters of a given linear model in the context of a real-world scenario.

Build a linear model using a first principles approach.

Build a feasible linear model using an empirical approach.

Define SSE and understand how minimizing it leads to an optimal solution for the parameters of a linear model.

Understand the connection between SSE and \(R^2\) as measurements of the fit of a model.

Build an optimal linear model using Excel trendline.

Use a linear model to make a prediction and interpret the results in the context of a realworld scenario.

Think through ethical considerations for using a linear model to make predictions.

title: 1Â  Lesson 20: Modeling with Linear Functions 1
text:
Letâ€™s get to the lesson

Building intuition


But before we do, letâ€™s talk coffee â˜•






â“ Question 1





A Waco coffee shop named Common Grounds sells a custom Baylor coffee cup for $10. If you use this mug in their shop, you only pay $3 for a coffee instead of the usual $3.50.
If you purchase this mug and buy 4 cups of coffee, how much have you spent?




























âœ… Answer 1





You spent $10 on the custom mug.
Then you bought 3 coffees at $3 each:
\[
\text{Total} \;=\; 10 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3\;=\;  \$22
\]
So after your first 4 cups, youâ€™ve shelled out $22 in all.




Key Terms






ğŸ“ What is the general form of a linear function?





A linear function can be written as:
\[
\hat{y} = mx + b
\]









ğŸ”¢ What does the variable x represent?





The variable \(x\) represents the input to the function.

Itâ€™s the independent variable
You choose or observe values of \(x\)










ğŸ“ˆ What does the parameter m represent?





The parameter \(m\) represents the slope of the line.

It tells you how much the output \(\hat{y}\) changes for each 1-unit increase in \(x\)
A larger \(m\) makes the line steeper
If \(m > 0\), the line increases
If \(m < 0\), the line decreases










ğŸ“ What does the parameter b represent?





The parameter \(b\) is the y-intercept.

Itâ€™s the value of the function when \(x = 0\)
It shifts the line up or down on the graph
It does not affect the slope










ğŸ¯ What does the variable \(\hat{y}\) represent?





The variable \(\hat{y}\) represents the predicted output of the function.

Itâ€™s the dependent variable
It shows the modelâ€™s best estimate based on the input \(x\)






So what did we really do here?


Code
library(shiny)
library(ggplot2)

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Adjust Linear Function"),
  
  # Plot output
  plotOutput("linePlot", height = "400px"),
  
  # Numeric inputs below the plot, side-by-side
  fluidRow(
    column(6,
           numericInput("m", "Slope (m):", value = 3, min = -5, max = 5, step = 0.1)
    ),
    column(6,
           numericInput("b", "Intercept (b):", value = 10, min = -20, max = 20, step = 1)
    )
  )
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  output$linePlot <- renderPlot({
    x <- seq(-10, 10, length.out = 100)
    y <- input$m * x + input$b
    df <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)
    
    ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
      geom_line(color = "#0072B2", linewidth = 1.5) +
      labs(
        title = bquote(hat(y) == .(input$m) * x + .(input$b)),
        x = "x", y = expression(hat(y))
      ) + 
      lims(x = c(0,10), y = c(0,40)) +
      theme_minimal(base_size = 16)
  })
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

text:
Team Problem
During in-processing, height and weight were recorded for all New Cadets. The data below shows a sample of five New Cadets. Your task is to build a model to estimate a New Cadetâ€™s weight based on their height.



Height (in)
Weight (lbs)




65
145


67
151


68
153


69
161


72
170





ğŸ›  Transform






ğŸ“‹ Given





A table of observed measurements









ğŸ¯ Find





A mathematical model that help us understand the relationship between a New Cadetâ€™s weight based on their height.









âœï¸ Define Variables





Let:

\(x\) = height in inches (independent variable)

\(\hat{y}\) = predicted weight in pounds (dependent variable)










ğŸ§  Make Assumptions






The relationship between height and weight is approximately linear over this range.
Other factors influencing weight are held constant.
The sample is representative of the New Cadet population.










ğŸ§® Develop Model














\[\hat{y} = mx + b\] Where:

\(m\) = slope of the line (change in predicted weight per inch of height)

\(b\) = y-intercept (estimated weight when height \(x = 0\))






ğŸ§® Solve
\(m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}\)
\(b = -mx_1 + y_1\)


ğŸ” Interpret
What would we expect the weight of someone one of the following heights?

70 inches?
66 inches?
60 inches?
24 inches?

Whatâ€™s going on here? When is this model appropriate?
